Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2014 07:27PM milehighgirl wrote: Hello ladies, newbie here so forgive me if I ask questions previously asked! Lymphedema just crept up on me and has now landed in one leg.  The last two days it looks like it may be moving into the other leg.  I've been really discouraged and depressed about this.  I'm all by myself so if I lose the use of my legs I'm toast. I do the exercises faithfully that the LPT has given me and wrap the leg the way I'm supposed to.  So many of you are doing heavy duty exercises.  Did you start where I'm at and build up to where you are now?  It's amazing that in about 6-weeks time I'm barely able to walk when I was able to take the stairs two at a time!  Is there hope for me to also build up to where you are now?  Need some encouragement! Sue
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 10:22AM milehighgirl wrote: What a neat idea Lia.  I wonder if soaking in Epsom salts would do the same.  I think I might try it tonight.  My legs are swollen, even though they've been wrapped.  This therapist sounds terrific.  Keep sharing!!!! GMA, it does stink we have to keep going through this.  I was told that my swelling would go down as I went through rads.  I know it's been just under a week.  I'm hoping it's not going to take weeks or months for the rads to kick in and start working.  Praying you get a reprieve from all of this! Sue

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2014 11:06AM milehighgirl wrote:  Well I just lost everything I've written the last 5-minutes.  Will try again. Carol, so sorry to hear about all you're going through.  Tell your friend it's not over 'till it's over.  Doctor's are simply the messengers.  God has the real answers.  I'll be praying for you, your parents and your friend for the duration. I finally got in to  see the PT yesterday.  We did the massage and wrapping.  She taught me how to do the massage and it does make a difference.  Carol, I still swell more after I exercise.  I'm wondering if I'm just doing too much.  Now I exercise, elevate the leg afterward and massage the fluid up and out.  It is making a difference. Binney, I agree that gardening is huge when it comes to exercise.  I want to know how you're cooking your beets and cooling them for a snack.  Aren't they mushy after you cook them?  Share, share, share what you're doing with the beets!  I want to try it. I also have a friend who swears by the Epsom salt soaks for the hands and feet.  He has cured his neuropathy by soaking daily.  I'm going to give it a try today and then see if I can get the swelling down far enough so as to give myself a pedicure.  Doesn't that count as exercise?  ha ha. Sue
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2014 12:18AM milehighgirl wrote: Binney, thank you for the instructions.  Can't wait to stop at the produce store on the way home tomorrow!  Swelling is going down as I do the massage.  It's pretty easy to do so I am able to do it more often.  I was put on the diuretics several months before the blood clot but I actually don't take them very often for a variety of reasons. ( I forget.  I have 14 other pills to take today.  Can't keep running to the bathroom at work so can't drink the required water, etc., etc., etc.,).  I've been pretty faithful doing the Lebed exercises.  Mostly upper body and breathing which my PT says is the very best for us to do.  Lots of oxygen!  I'll work up to the rest of it as I go along. Sue
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: May 2, 2014 05:32PM milehighgirl wrote: Jeannie you are indeed lucky to have Sherry come to your class.  Everyone and their mother likely has recommended books and literature to Sherry but I'm just about finished with a newly released book (March) called "Radical Remission" by Kelly Turner.  It is an awesome book and she's one of the first to collect research on people who have healed themselves of all kinds of cancers.  Her data is from people she's talked to all over the world.  I've been recommending it to everyone who will listen, lol.  The last guy I recommended it to took it to one of his classes and the entire class went online and ordered themselves a copy! Anyway, just a thought.  Sue
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 11:42PM milehighgirl wrote: Carol, I bookmarked all of the Lebed openings.  I think there are 10 of them.  I also went to the website to look at ordering the DVD but wasn't sure which one it was.  Could you please post the link to the right one? I'd like to know how you're all doing these exercises.  I have trouble walking along with breathing issues.  I'm having another surgery next week to hopefully take care of the lung problem so maybe that will help with the exercise.  It's hard to exercise when you can only go two steps without feeling like you're going to pass out.  I do try to force myself to do the walks and such but end up with more swelling.  I do have the bands and use those here and there.  Haven't been able to do the rebounder because of the breathing.  Any ideas of what else I could do?  I'm especially interested in trunk/abdomen exercises. Thank you all!  Sue

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 04:57PM milehighgirl wrote: Okay ladies.  I don't know how you're doing all these exercises without things getting worse.  I emailed my PT today to ask about what might work to get the fluid moving again.  All the exercises I've done and what she's given me have made the leg more swollen to the point I can't bend my leg to reach my foot to put a wrap or sock on.  Eeeeek!  Also waiting for the blood thinning shots to start working on the blood clot.  Anyone know how long that might take before some of the swelling goes down?  I'm nervous about the leg being so swollen.  Also done the diuretics today and lots of water along side the exercise and walking.  Getting discouraged. Any and all ideas are welcome.  Keep up the good work!  Sue

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2014 08:16PM milehighgirl wrote: mnm, when I was taken off the hormone blockers last June and went back to chemo, the weight that wouldn't budge dropped off of me very quickly.  That was pre-LE.  The only weight I've put back on is the 20 lbs of lymphatic fluid that I have trouble moving out of my leg.  My LE pump is due here Friday and I can't wait for it to get here.  Should make a huge difference in my swollen legs and a lot easier than trying to do the manual myself.  I would love to be able to go back to my long walks but I can barely walk now. I'm also convinced that my LE got worse when I had radiation to the tumor in my LE leg.  Swelling went from just my calf to my calf and thigh.  My arm also started swelling again after a long hiatus.  Doesn't matter whether I wear my compressions or exercise.  I'm just having a hard time getting this to go away.  It doesn't mean yours will get worse or won't ever go away.  I think we're all pretty much different in what works and what doesn't. Laurel, what a great picture!  Glad you were able to make an "escape"! Sue
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: May 3, 2014 09:58AM milehighgirl wrote: Carol, the book is about people who were sent home to die with no more conventional treatments that would work.  I believe there are a few people who did both but I'm only about 2/3rds of the way through the book.  I was sent home to die 5-years ago and I'm still kicking.  I'm convinced that it was the alternatives that have kept me going so I've read literally hundreds of these types of books.  So far, this is one of the best one's I've come across because she actually researched what people were doing.  Whereas the medical profession isn't interested in alternatives so she set out to give them something to really look at.  Very much worth a read.  Sue
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 02:56AM milehighgirl wrote: Flimsicle, welcome to the neuropathy club.  I've had the same foot issue in one foot along with lymphedema up the leg.  Thus, I am numb from the knee to the toes and yes, it is neuropathy you're experiencing.  I have tingling in my other foot (toes only) and the fingertips of both hands.  I've had to deal with this for awhile and I'm nervous about the Halaven making it worse.  It doesn't sound like yours is too bad though so we'll keep our fingers crossed. I feel for you on the appetite.  I'm not a big eater to begin with so when/if this drug really cranks up, I'll be able to give you some insights.  Maybe trying to eat smaller meals throughout the day would help you.  I've had the extreme fatigue you talk about.  Today I made it to 5:00 before crashing for a late afternoon nap.  I tried so hard not to take it lol. Good luck!  Sue
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 05:40AM milehighgirl wrote: Flim, I'm going to have to try the headache thing as it sounds wonderful.  I can't take anything over the counter so I just have to live with the aches and pains when they come. I'm guessing that your onc. would agree to giving you two weeks off.  Mine would if my fatigue got really bad.  The last drug I was on did a number on my platelets and we kept postponing the next infusion until they came back up over 100 (the acceptable, lowest number to get chemo).  I had also asked to have my dosage reduced and spread further apart.  My tired, old body just wasn't bouncing back like it did the first go 'round 5-years ago.  Guess it's harder the second time around.  I do wrap my leg almost every day for the lymphedema.  I see the PT tomorrow to try to figure out what to do about the abdominal/trunk swelling.  My swelling started out in my arm and then went away.  Then my leg ballooned and now the trunk.  I'm with you that I just want all of this to GO AWAY, lol.  I keep saying though that for each day that we live on, someone out there is getting that much closer to a cure.  Just think.  I was dx'd in 2009 and most of the drugs I've had this go around didn't exist then.  We are going to beat this ladies.  So let's push on! Thanks for the info flimsical!  Sue

Blessings.  Sue

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 06:13PM milehighgirl wrote: Jean I'm with you on the waiting game.  Monday will be here in no time.  And what's up with the lung issue?  Mine returned with a vengeance this weekend.  I didn't think taking a hiatus from chemo would bring it back so fast.  Had 3 thorocentisis last summer and then started on the chemo.  Lungs seemed to be drying up nicely after that.  Jean we'll keep our fingers crossed you get a good result on your tests. Today I can barely walk because of the shortness of breath.  Sat in the Dr.'s office yesterday and we decided my oxygen levels were at or above normal so no need to schedule the thorocentisis.  I can't believe how out of breath I am only 24 hours later!  Hope I don't end up in the ER tonight.  I'm scheduled to work on Monday so I'll have to call for the appointment on one of my breaks.  Why do these things only pop up on the weekends?  I'm wondering if the rads I had this week and last are causing the reoccurrence along with the leg swelling.  I was so hoping not to have to have this again and let the new chemo do it's thing with the lungs.  I'm bummed.  Sue

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2014 08:25PM milehighgirl wrote: Pearlady, you are one of the lucky ones.  I dealt with the "c" from one of my anti-nausea drugs (Zofran).  The only thing that worked for me was a natural product called Perdiem.  I got it at Walmart and it was very gentle and they guarantee it to work.  It did. So far, I've just had the first infusion.  I've had extreme fatigue and a runny nose - go figure.  A bit of a funny stomach here and there but no real nausea. Barb, I read that one of the side effects was anemia and low red and white counts.  If that's what you're experiencing, then you would have some dizziness.  My last chemo did a number on my counts.  I got dizzy at work one day and didn't know what it was from.  My onc. told me I was anemic but I had no idea until then that I was. Dancing veggie, are you doing better?  Hope you got that fever under control! Sue

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2013 07:45PM milehighgirl wrote: Marsha, DO NOT give up.  I agree with everyone here that a second opinion is worth pursuing.  My younger sister battled for 12 years before all of the current drugs and treatments were available. She was told over and over that "there was nothing else we can do".  Hockey Puck!  She went somewhere else, got a different treatment and low and behold was back in remission - at one point for three years! You can also look into alternative and/or complementary therapies.  I've used several on the cancertutor.com website which has an assortment of things you can try.  My (old) doctor told me to go home and wait to die four years ago.  That doctor is no longer there but I am and still going strong and no one can figure out why I'm still alive. You go girl.  You've got a ton of support here and hundreds of us cheering you on. Blessings, Sue
